page.title: 03GOLDEN CAP
page.content: Golden Cap Seatown, dominated by Golden cap, is part of the parish of Chideock and used to belong to the manor. It is one of the many places owned by the National Trust, it is the highest point on the south west coast. Gales have cost Seatown dear because such as November 23 1824 have wrecked several houses including a farmhouse on the seaward side of the Anchor Inn, and a road leading in the direction of Golden Cap, was often a tempory hideout to smuggle goods. A hundred and fifty years ago there was a coast guard station on the top of Golden Cap it is a beauty spot for visitors because from the top you can see all the way from Portland around to Torquay, the sides are steep but the top is reasonably flat. It is 191 metres high.
